name: Gravimetric moisture determination
description: Measurement of the amount of water in soil by weighing a sample before and after drying it in an oven at a temperature of 100–110 degrees Celsius. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Neutron probe
description: Measurment of the moisture content and hence the porosity of a geological formation by means of lowering a tool containing a radioactive element emitting neutrons and a neutron detector into a borehole. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Electrical resistance blocks (Porous blocks)
description: Determination of electrical resistance between two electrodes embedded in blocks of a porous material buried in the ground and in equilibrium with the surrounding moist soil Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: Tensiometer
description: Measurement of soil capillary tension by means of a porous cup, inserted in the soil, connected to a manometer by a water-filled tube. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Time domain reflectometry (TDR)
description: Estimation of water content in unsaturated materials based on variations in their dielectric properties. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Ultrasonic ranging
description: Transmission of an ultrasonic pulse towards the target and listening for a return echo from that target.

name: Graduated device
description: Manual measurement or observation made with a graduated fixed stake, a sturdy ruler, or an extendable graduated rod.

path: \Terrestrial\Water equivalent of snow cover\Snow pillows and snow scales
name: Snow pillows and snow scales
description: Weighing of snow-cover mass per unit area.

name: Laser ranging
description: Emission of a modulated beam of light in the visible spectrum to determine the distance to a target by comparing the phase information from the reflected beam.

name: Echo sounding
description: Evaluation of the return time of acoustic waves emitted into a medium to determine the distance between source and target. E.g. used in hydrology to determine the depth of a water body. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Frequency domain reflectometry
description: Measurement of soil capacitance by means of radio frequency waves. The soil acts as the dielectric completing a capacitance circuit, which is part of a feedback loop of a high-frequency transistor oscillator Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: Gamma-ray attenuation
description: Determination of gamma-ray attenuation at given depth of soil using a source and a detector placed at a given distance at the same depth. If the apparent dry bulk density of the soil is known the signal can be converted into a measure of the volumetric soil-moisture content. Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168) 2008 (6th ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, non-recording
name: Non-recording gauge
description: Determination of water stage by means of a non-recording gauge (e.g., graduated vertical or inclined staff gauge, wire-weight gauge, graduated rod, tape or point gauge and maximum-stage gauge) Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, non-recording
name: Staff gauge
description: Determination of water stage by means of a graduated vertical scale, fixed to a staff or structure, on which the water level may be read (syn. vertical gauge). International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, non-recording
name: Inclined gauge
description: Determination of water stage by means of a non-vertical scale which is graduated to indicate vertical heights. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, non-recording
name: Wire-weight gauge
description: Determination of water stage by means of a fine cable or wire attached to a weight which is lowered to the water surface in order to determine its position below a fixed above-surface point. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, non-recording
name: Point gauge
description: Level measurement gauge, the essential element of which is a pointed rod that is lowered until it touches the water surface. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Maximum-stage gauge
description: Determination of the elevation of the flood crest by the adherence of regranulated cork to a graduated staff held in a fixed position with relation to the datum. Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, recording
name: Recording gauge
description: Determination of water stage by means of a recording gauge, i.e. a device that automatically records the water level as detected by a sensor, either continuously or at regular time intervals (syn. limnigraph, stage recorder, water-level recorder). International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, recording
name: Wire-float recording gauge (hydrograph)
description: Determination of water stage by means of a gauge consisting of a float which rises and falls with changes in the water level; this movement being transmitted to a recording or indicating device. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

path: hydrological, water stage, in situ, recording
name: Pressure-actuated recording gauge
description: Determination of water stage by means of a pressure-actuated recording gauge, i.e. a device that operates on the principle that static pressure at a fixed point in the stream is directly proportional to the head of liquid above the point. This relation is described by the following equation: Water level = (P_static – P_atm ) C, where P_static is the pressure in bar on a fixed spot in the water column, P_atm is the atmospheric pressure in bar on the surface of the water column, and C is a factor of the water’s net weight (C = 10.2 for freshwater at 20°C), which changes with the temperature and salinity of the water. Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: Velocity-area method
description: Determination of the discharge of a stream by measuring the velocity of the flowing water and the depth of the water at a number of points over the cross-section, and summing the products of mean velocities by elemental areas. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Float gauging
description: Measurement of the velocity of a stream by means of a float or velocity rod. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Dilution gauging
description: Determination of the discharge of a stream by measuring the degree of dilution, caused by the flowing water, of an added tracer solution (syn. chemical gauging, tracer dilution gauging). International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Slope-area method
description: Determination of the discharge in a reach which is based on the surface slope, the reach roughness, the wetted perimeters and the flow areas of the various wetted cross-sections in the reach. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Measuring weir
description: Determination of the discharge of a stream by means of a device or structure across the stream which causes a free or submerged fall. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Flume
description: Determination of the discharge of a stream by means of a man-made channel with clearly specified shape and dimensions. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Stage-discharge relation
description: Determination of the discharge of a stream by means of a relationship between water level and discharge for a given cross-section, which may be expressed as a curve, a table or an equation. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Water current meter
description: Determination of water velocity by means of a current meter, i.e. an instrument for measuring water velocity. (syn. flowmeter) International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Cup-type current meter
description: Determination of water velocity by means of a current meter whose rotor is composed of a wheel fitted with cups turning on a vertical axis. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Propeller-type current meter
description: Determination of water velocity by means of a current meter in which the rotor is a propeller rotating around an axis parallel to the flow International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Acoustic (ultrasonic) velocity meter
description: Measurement of the difference in travel time of acoustic (ultrasonic) pulses between transducers in a stream to determine the mean velocity on the signal path. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Acoustic doppler current profiler (ADCP)
description: Determination of stream discharge by means of an ADCP instrument mounted on a moving vessel. The instrument uses an acoustic doppler transducer to measure water velocity, depth and vessel path simultaneously to compute discharge. As the instrument processes the signal reflected off the particles in the water, it divides the water column into a number of discrete segments stacked in the vertical (i.e. depth cells) and determines the velocity and direction of each segment, while the signal from the bottom (i.e. bottom-track) measures the speed and direction of the boat. Once the profile is finished the instrument calculates the total discharge and the operation is repeated a number of times, to give the river discharge estimate as the average value. Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: Acoustic doppler current meter
description: Determination of stream velocity by means of an acoustic Doppler instrument, which measures the velocity of the water using the Doppler shift principle. The instrument transmits an acoustic pulse of energy into the water which is reflected off particles suspended in, and moving with, the water and some of it returns to the instrument. The instrument measures the Doppler shift (change in frequency) of the reflected energy and uses this to compute the velocity of the water relative to the instrument. The reflected pulses have a frequency (Doppler) shift proportional to the velocities of the scatterers they are travelling in along the acoustic beam: V = ( F_d / 2 F_0 ) C, where F_d is the Doppler shifted frequency received at the transducer, F_0 is the transducer transmit frequency, C is the sound speed, and V is the scatterer (water) velocity . Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: Optical or nuclear suspended-sediment gauge
description: Determination of the decrease of intensity of a visible light or X-rays beam by means of a photoelectric or nuclear detector situated at constant distance from the source of the beam. This decrease, caused by the scattering and/or absorption by suspended-sediment particles, is proportional to the sediment concentration, if other relevant characteristics of water and sediment (chemical, mineral composition, etc.) remain unchanged. Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: Gravimetric sediment measurement
description: Estimation of the total sediment in a water sample by allowing the sediment to settle in a container, siphoning off the supernatant water, carefully transferring all the sediment from the container on to filter paper, then drying the sample and determining the mass of total sediment. International Glossary of Hydrology (WMO-No. 385), 2012 (3rd ed.)

name: Displacement method of sediments
description: Determination of sediment concentration by the measurement of the difference in weight between a sample of sediment-laden water and an equal volume of clear water at the same temperature. The dry weight of sediment is computed as: W_s = k (W_ws - W_w), where k = q_s/(q-q_s), in which W_s is the weight of sediment to be determined; W_ws is the weight of the specific gravity flask plus the weight of sediment water mixture; W_w is the weight of the specific gravity flask plus the weight of clear water; q_s is density of sediment particles; q is density of water. Manual on Sediment Management and Measurement (WMO-No. 948), 2003

name: Water discharge-sediment discharge rating curve
description: Computation of sediment discharge from a record of stream discharges by means of a rating curve built from systematic samples of suspended-sediment concentration taken during low, medium and high flows Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: Water discharge-bed material rating curve
description: Computation of bed material discharge from a record of stream discharges by means of a rating curve built from systematic samples of bed material discharge taken during low, medium and high flows. Guide to Hydrological Practices, (WMO-No. 168), 2008 (6th ed.)

name: inapplicable
description: None of the codes in the table are applicable in the context of this particular observation.

name: unknown
description: The measurement/observing method is unknown.
